text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-Ten MPs handed an urgent draft law to speaker of the parliament Berri demanding a five-month grace period for the mass of private television and radio stations ordered to shut down by the end of this month.
-Israeli shelling wounded two civilians in south Lebanon.
-Lebanon's total public debt reaches 17,983 billion pounds.
-Lebanese businessmen take part in the Cairo economic summit despite Beirut's boycott of the meeting.
-Workers of Lebanon's cargo carrier Trans Mediterranean Airlines (TMA) returned to work following a four month stoppage.
-Despite the negotiations with the Minister of Education, the teachers' unions reiterated that school teachers will go on the one-day strike tomorrow on pay scale demands.
-The new cabinet postponed its first meeting because of differences on the ministerial statement among the members of the statement's members.
-Two new containers of plastic toxic wastes were found in Beirut port and police is searching for their owners.
-A Palestinean delegation will arrive in Lebanon today.
-Iran denies that it has any information on the fate of Israeli pilot Arad who went missing in Lebanon in 1986.
